items.title: Airglow & Mesospheric Gravity Waves
items.summary: Natural night-sky glow and wave patterns reveal upper‑atmospheric dynamics unrelated to city lights.
items.what_it_is: Chemiluminescent emissions (e.g., OH airglow near ~85–90 km) modulated by atmospheric gravity waves that propagate from lower levels.
items.how_it_works: Wave breaking and ducting shape ripples/bands visible in sensitive imagery; background chemistry and tides modulate brightness.
items.typical_values_note: Wave wavelengths tens to hundreds of km; phase speeds tens of m·s⁻¹.
observational_cues: Nighttime imagery with rippled structures; conditions favoring visibility (clear, dark, low moonlight).
items.common_misconceptions: “Airglow equals aurora.” Different mechanisms: chemiluminescence vs particle precipitation.

items.title: Airglow‑Correct Twilight & Milky Way Windows
items.summary: Practical skywatching windows depend on twilight class, moon altitude/phase, and seasonal Milky Way geometry.
items.what_it_is: A planning framework that combines astronomical darkness, moonlight, and galactic center position to forecast visibility.
items.how_it_works: Compute sun/moon elevation vs time, mask windows with solar depression < −18°, and evaluate galactic center altitude for a given observer and season.
items.typical_values_note: Windows typically a few hours per night in season; airmass increases rapidly at low altitude.
observational_cues: Per‑location time bars for darkness vs moon; galactic center rise/set charts; cloud cover overlays.
items.common_misconceptions: “New Moon guarantees great views.” Clouds, haze, and light pollution still dominate outcomes.
search_terms: astronomy windows milky way airglow moon

items.title: Aurora Physics: Emission Lines & Colors
items.summary: Auroral colors arise from specific atmospheric emissions at characteristic altitudes and particle energies.
items.what_it_is: Visible emissions from oxygen and nitrogen excited by precipitating particles along magnetic field lines.
items.how_it_works: Electron/proton precipitation excites species that emit at key wavelengths as they return to lower energy states—green 557.7 nm O (~100–150 km), red 630.0 nm O (~200–300 km), blue/violet bands from N₂⁺ (~427.8 nm).
items.typical_values_note: Altitude bands (km); Wavelengths (nm).
observational_cues: Auroral oval with color legend; altitude strips; example spectra/imagery for public education.
items.common_misconceptions: “All green aurora is the same height.” Heights vary with composition, energy, and local conditions.

items.title: Coronal Holes & High-Speed Streams (HSS)
items.summary: Dark EUV regions with open magnetic fields emit fast solar wind that can trigger recurrent geomagnetic activity as the Sun rotates.
items.what_it_is: Coronal holes are areas of low-density, open-field corona. They are sources of high-speed solar wind streams (HSS) that co-rotate with the Sun.
items.how_it_works: Open field lines allow plasma to escape more freely, creating fast streams. Where fast wind overtakes slow wind, co-rotating interaction regions (CIRs) form and can enhance geomagnetic activity when they reach Earth.
items.typical_values_note: HSS speeds commonly 500–800 km·s⁻¹ versus ambient ~300–400 km·s⁻¹.
observational_cues: EUV imagery showing coronal holes; predicted HSS arrival windows; Kp increases in recurrent patterns (~27‑day cadence).
items.common_misconceptions: “Coronal holes are holes in the Sun.” They are magnetically open, not physical cavities.

items.title: Cosmic Rays & Forbush Decreases
items.summary: Galactic cosmic‑ray flux at Earth varies with solar activity; sudden drops (Forbush decreases) follow CME passages.
items.what_it_is: High‑energy particles from outside the solar system modulated by the heliospheric magnetic field and solar wind.
items.how_it_works: Stronger solar wind and magnetic turbulence during active periods scatter and exclude cosmic rays, reducing counts; CME‑driven disturbances cause rapid, temporary decreases measured by neutron monitors.
items.typical_values_note: Count rates are relative to station baselines; decreases a few percent to >10% during significant events.
observational_cues: Station time series; annotated events; correlations with Kp/Dst and CME arrivals.
items.common_misconceptions: “Cosmic rays always drop during any flare.” It’s the interplanetary disturbance that drives the decrease.

items.title: Day–Night Cloud Detection (DNB & Thermal Differencing)
items.summary: Night cloud detection relies on moonlight‑sensitive visible bands and thermal IR differences rather than daytime reflectance.
items.what_it_is: Techniques using low‑light visible sensors (e.g., Day/Night Band) and thermal split‑window differences (e.g., 3.9–11 µm) to identify fog/low cloud at night.
items.how_it_works: Under moonlight, DNB captures reflected light from clouds; thermal differences exploit emissivity/temperature contrasts between cloud and surface.
items.typical_values_note: Signal depends on lunar phase/angle; thermal difference thresholds are sensor‑dependent.
observational_cues: Fog/low cloud detection composites; confidence masks; lunar illumination overlays.
items.common_misconceptions: “If it’s dark, satellites can’t see clouds.” Low‑light sensors and thermal IR provide robust night detection.
search_terms: day night cloud detection dnb thermal

items.title: Earth Orientation: Polar Motion & Length‑of‑Day (LOD)
items.summary: Small changes in Earth’s rotation and pole position occur due to angular‑momentum exchange with atmosphere and oceans.
items.what_it_is: Polar motion (x,y) and LOD anomalies relative to UTC; needed for precise timing and pointing systems.
items.how_it_works: Seasonal and episodic mass/wind changes shift Earth’s rotation axis and rate. Geophysical fluids exchange angular momentum with the solid Earth.
items.typical_values_note: LOD variations on the order of milliseconds; polar motion on the order of milliarcseconds.
observational_cues: LOD anomaly timelines; polar‑motion plots; context callouts during major anomalies.
items.common_misconceptions: “These changes affect daily life strongly.” Effects are tiny but important for precision applications.

items.title: Eclipses (Solar/Lunar) & Transit Geometry
items.summary: Precise alignments of Sun, Moon, and Earth create eclipses with calculable paths, timings, and obscuration.
items.what_it_is: Solar eclipses (Moon blocks Sun: total/annular/partial) and lunar eclipses (Earth’s shadow on Moon). Planetary transits are small bodies crossing the solar disk.
items.how_it_works: Alignments near lunar nodes produce umbra/penumbra footprints; local contact times define event phases (C1–C4).
items.typical_values_note: Path widths and durations vary; totality often a few minutes at maximum.
observational_cues: Ground tracks; local obscuration %; contact times; safety notes for solar viewing (filters).
items.common_misconceptions: “Annular equals total.” Annular leaves a bright ring (Moon smaller than Sun).

items.title: F10.7 cm Solar Radio Flux
items.summary: The 10.7 cm (2800 MHz) radio flux is a stable proxy for solar EUV output and overall activity.
items.what_it_is: A daily measurement of solar radio emission at 10.7 cm wavelength. It correlates with solar EUV irradiance and thermospheric/ionospheric heating.
items.how_it_works: Enhanced magnetic activity increases gyro-resonance and bremsstrahlung radio emissions. F10.7 tracks active regions and the solar cycle, aiding ionospheric and thermospheric models.
items.typical_values_note: Quiet Sun ~65–75 sfu; active conditions often >120 sfu; values >200 sfu indicate strong activity.
observational_cues: Daily F10.7 plots and 81‑day running means; regime bands for low/medium/high activity; model inputs for TEC/thermosphere density.
items.common_misconceptions: “F10.7 directly measures flares.” It is a broadband proxy of activity, not a flare detector.
tags: solar flux unit sfu 10 w m hz
search_terms: solar flux unit sfu 10 w m hz

items.title: Geomagnetic Indices (Kp, Dst, AE) & Auroral Oval
items.summary: Indices summarize geomagnetic activity and help estimate auroral visibility and storm severity.
items.what_it_is: Kp (0–9) gauges global activity; Dst (nT) measures ring-current strength (negative during storms); AE/AL/AU track high‑latitude electrojet variability. The auroral oval outlines typical aurora latitude for given activity.
items.how_it_works: Solar-wind energy input intensifies currents and particle precipitation. Kp rises with global disturbance; Dst drops as the ring current strengthens; AE spikes during substorms.
items.typical_values_note: Kp ≥5 = storm; Dst below −50 nT = storm-level; AE often >1000 nT during active substorms.
observational_cues: Live/forecast Kp; Dst curves; dynamic auroral oval maps; “visible-aurora” latitude bands.
items.common_misconceptions: “Kp shows local aurora certainty.” It’s global—use latitude/time and cloud cover for local visibility.
search_terms: geomagnetic indices kp dst ae auroral oval

items.title: Interplanetary Magnetic Field (IMF) & Bz
items.summary: Sustained southward IMF Bz enhances dayside reconnection and is the single most important parameter for storm strength.
items.what_it_is: The magnetic field embedded in the solar wind, measured at L1 and decomposed into components (Bx, By, Bz) in GSM/GSE coordinates. Bz < 0 (southward) is geoeffective.
items.how_it_works: Southward Bz opposes Earth’s northward geomagnetic field at the dayside magnetopause, enabling magnetic reconnection and energy transfer into the magnetosphere–ionosphere system.
items.typical_values_note: Bz swings from positive to negative; sustained Bz ≤ −5 to −10 nT for hours often heralds strong storms.
observational_cues: Real-time Bx/By/Bz and clock-angle plots; risk bars highlighting prolonged southward Bz episodes.
items.common_misconceptions: “Any negative Bz triggers a big storm.” Duration and magnitude both matter, as does solar-wind speed/pressure.

items.title: Ionospheric TEC & Scintillation
items.summary: Total Electron Content (TEC) controls GPS signal delay; small‑scale irregularities cause scintillation and outages.
items.what_it_is: Column-integrated electron density (TECU = 10¹⁶ electrons·m⁻²) and rapid amplitude/phase fluctuations (scintillation) that degrade radio links.
items.how_it_works: Solar EUV and geomagnetic forcing set background TEC; traveling disturbances and equatorial spread‑F create irregularities that scatter radio waves, increasing errors or loss of lock.
items.typical_values_note: Mid‑latitude TEC typically ~5–30 TECU; equatorial anomaly regions can exceed 50+ TECU.
observational_cues: Global/continental TEC maps; ROTI/scintillation hotspots; day–night and storm‑time asymmetries.
items.common_misconceptions: “High TEC always means bad GPS.” High, smooth TEC mainly adds delay; irregularities drive outages.

items.title: Lagrange Points & Spacecraft Monitors (L1/L2)
items.summary: Spacecraft at gravitational balance points provide upstream solar‑wind data (L1) and deep‑space observation platforms (L2).
items.what_it_is: Stable/semistable points in the Sun–Earth system where gravitational and centrifugal forces balance.
items.how_it_works: L1 sits between Earth and Sun for upstream monitoring; L2 lies beyond Earth on the night side, ideal for astronomy with steady thermal environment.
items.typical_values_note: Distance ~1.5 million km from Earth for L1/L2.
observational_cues: Diagrams showing L1/L2 positions; data latency context (solar wind travel time tens of minutes).
items.common_misconceptions: “Lagrange points are stationary points in space.” They co‑rotate with the Earth–Sun system; spacecraft use halo/Lissajous orbits.

items.title: Lunar Geometry: Distance, Libration & Illumination
items.summary: The Moon’s distance varies (perigee/apogee), and libration reveals slightly different lunar faces; illumination sets phase.
items.what_it_is: Orbital eccentricity changes apparent size and brightness; libration in longitude/latitude tilts the visible disk; phase is the Sun‑Moon‑Earth angle.
items.how_it_works: Elliptical orbit and axial tilt cause cyclic distance and viewing geometry changes; illumination fraction depends on phase angle.
items.typical_values_note: Distance ~356,000–406,000 km; illumination 0–100% across synodic month (~29.5 days).
observational_cues: Per‑date distance/phase/libration plots; “supermoon/micromoon” flags; rise/set times.
items.common_misconceptions: “Supermoon drastically changes tides weather.” Tidal range changes are modest; weather impacts are indirect.

items.title: Magnetopause & Bow Shock Stand‑off Distance
items.summary: Solar‑wind pressure compresses Earth’s magnetosphere; the subsolar magnetopause distance shrinks during disturbances.
items.what_it_is: Boundaries where the solar wind slows and diverts (bow shock) and where solar‑wind/magnetospheric pressure balance (magnetopause).
items.how_it_works: Pressure balance sets stand‑off distances; increases in solar‑wind dynamic pressure move boundaries Earthward.
items.typical_values_note: Quiet subsolar magnetopause near ~10 Earth radii (Re), but variable with pressure and IMF.
observational_cues: Estimated stand‑off vs pressure plots; GEO orbit ring for context; alerts when compression risks GEO.
items.common_misconceptions: “Distance depends only on speed.” It depends on density, speed (pressure), and IMF conditions.

items.title: Meteors & Meteor Showers (Radiants & Rates)
items.summary: Annual meteor showers arise when Earth crosses debris streams, producing predictable radiant locations and peak rates.
items.what_it_is: Swarms of meteoroids from parent comets/asteroids intersect Earth’s orbit; apparent origin point is the radiant in the sky.
items.how_it_works: As Earth passes through the stream, encounter geometry and particle density set the zenithal hourly rate (ZHR). Moonlight and cloud cover reduce observed counts.
items.typical_values_note: Major showers peak ZHR from ~20 to 100+; sporadic background ~5–10/hr under dark skies.
observational_cues: Radiant maps; peak windows; moonlight interference index; observer‑location adjusted expectations.
items.common_misconceptions: “ZHR equals what I’ll see.” ZHR assumes ideal dark, zenith radiant, and perfect conditions.

items.title: Night‑Sky Brightness & Light Pollution
items.summary: Sky brightness from artificial lights and the Moon sets the visibility of faint celestial features.
items.what_it_is: Measures of radiance/magnitude that quantify sky glow; Bortle classes summarize observing conditions.
items.how_it_works: Upward‑scattered light and atmospheric aerosols raise background brightness; moon phase and altitude add natural light.
items.typical_values_note: Dark‑sky sites ~21–22 mag·arcsec⁻²; urban cores <18 mag·arcsec⁻² (brighter).
observational_cues: Radiance maps; Bortle approximations; moonlight masks; cloud overlays.
items.common_misconceptions: “Clouds always harm observations equally.” Clouds can reflect city light and worsen urban glow more than rural sites.

items.title: Noctilucent Clouds (Polar Mesospheric Clouds)
items.summary: Very high‑altitude ice clouds near 80–85 km appear in summer twilight at high latitudes.
items.what_it_is: Ice particles forming near the mesopause under very low temperatures; observed as bright, wispy structures after sunset/before sunrise.
items.how_it_works: Water vapor and condensation nuclei allow ice formation under extreme cold; mesospheric dynamics and solar activity modulate occurrence.
items.typical_values_note: Altitudes ~80–85 km; seasonal windows centered on local summer at high latitudes.
observational_cues: Probability/occurrence maps; recent observation galleries; twilight geometry aids.
items.common_misconceptions: “NLCs are tropospheric clouds.” They are mesospheric and unrelated to weather clouds.

items.title: Planetary Positions, Conjunctions & Occultations
items.summary: Apparent sky positions of planets follow predictable ephemerides, yielding conjunctions and occasional occultations.
items.what_it_is: Geometric alignments as seen from Earth; elongation and opposition control visibility; occultations occur when the Moon or a planet passes in front of another.
items.how_it_works: Orbital mechanics sets RA/Dec and altitude/azimuth vs time for any observer; conjunctions reflect small angular separations on the sky.
items.typical_values_note: Angular separations in degrees/arcminutes; times in UTC/local.
observational_cues: Sky charts with conjunction lines; horizon plots; per‑observer visibility windows.
items.common_misconceptions: “Conjunctions mean close physically.” They are line‑of‑sight alignments.

items.title: Proton Events & Polar Cap Absorption (PCA)
items.summary: Solar energetic proton events increase ionization at high latitudes, degrading HF comms via polar cap absorption.
items.what_it_is: Elevated fluxes of >10 MeV protons from solar eruptions; operationally categorized (S‑scale) by intensity.
items.how_it_works: Protons follow magnetic field lines into polar regions, enhancing D‑region ionization and absorbing HF signals; effects can persist hours to days.
items.typical_values_note: Thresholds for S1 start at ~10 pfu (proton flux units); stronger events reach hundreds to thousands pfu.
observational_cues: Polar absorption masks; proton flux timelines; warnings for polar aviation routes.
items.common_misconceptions: “Only flares cause PCA.” CME‑driven particle acceleration is a frequent driver.

items.title: Planetary Waves & Quasi‑Biennial Oscillation (QBO) (Concept)
items.summary: Alternating easterly/westerly winds in the tropical stratosphere modulate global circulation and can nudge seasonal patterns.
items.what_it_is: A ~28‑month oscillation of equatorial stratospheric winds (QBO) interacting with planetary waves and affecting downstream weather probabilities.
items.how_it_works: Wave–mean flow interactions propagate shear zones downward; phase influences vertical coupling and teleconnections in the extratropics.
items.typical_values_note: Phase durations months to a couple of years; indices in m·s⁻¹ at standard levels (e.g., 30 hPa).
observational_cues: QBO phase timelines; conceptual impact panels on jet latitude/storm tracks.
items.common_misconceptions: “QBO predicts specific storms.” It modulates probabilities, not deterministic events.

items.title: Radiation Belts & Energetic Electron Flux
items.summary: Trapped radiation in the Van Allen belts intensifies during storms, threatening satellite electronics.
items.what_it_is: Two primary belts (inner, outer) of trapped particles, with MeV‑range electron enhancements during geomagnetic activity.
items.how_it_works: Wave–particle interactions and injections accelerate and scatter electrons; slot region between belts can fill during strong events.
items.typical_values_note: Fluxes reported by energy channels (keV–MeV); hazard thresholds vary by orbit and hardware tolerance.
observational_cues: Electron flux timelines; storm‑time enhancement flags; orbit‑dependent risk overlays.
items.common_misconceptions: “All radiation effects are from protons.” Electrons are a major contributor in GEO/MEO hazards.

items.title: Solar Cycle & Sunspot Number
items.summary: Solar magnetic activity varies on ~11-year cycles, tracked by sunspot counts that correlate with space-weather risk.
items.what_it_is: A quasi-periodic cycle in the Sun’s magnetic field strength and polarity, observed through sunspots (cooler, magnetically intense regions). The 11-year cycle (Schwabe) nests within a 22-year magnetic polarity (Hale) cycle.
items.how_it_works: The solar dynamo in the convection zone amplifies and reorganizes magnetic fields. Twisted fields emerge as sunspot pairs near mid-latitudes and migrate equatorward as the cycle progresses (“butterfly diagram”). Activity rises toward solar maximum and falls toward minimum.
items.typical_values_note: Daily/Monthly SSN (dimensionless). 13‑month smoothed SSN is a common metric. Cycle lengths ~9–14 years.
observational_cues: Sunspot counts/indices timelines; EUV images with more active regions near maximum; increased flare/CME frequency.
items.common_misconceptions: “Solar maximum equals constant storms.” Activity is elevated on average, but storms occur intermittently.

items.title: Solar EUV & Radio Blackouts (R‑Scale Concept)
items.summary: Strong solar flares boost X‑ray/EUV output, causing short‑wave radio absorption on the dayside (radio blackouts).
items.what_it_is: Operational categorization of HF communication impacts based on solar X‑ray flux levels (R1–R5).
items.how_it_works: Enhanced X‑ray/EUV increases ionization in the D‑region ionosphere, absorbing HF signals and degrading GNSS accuracy on the sunlit hemisphere.
items.typical_values_note: Impacts scale from minor (R1) to extreme (R5), generally associated with flare classes from M to large X events.
observational_cues: Dayside absorption masks; flare timelines; sunlit hemisphere impact shading.
items.common_misconceptions: “Blackouts affect the whole Earth.” Effects are strongest on the dayside and along HF paths.

items.title: Solar Terminator & Twilight Geometry
items.summary: The Sun’s depression angle below the horizon defines civil, nautical, and astronomical twilight and controls sky brightness.
items.what_it_is: A geometric classification of twilight by solar elevation: civil (0° to −6°), nautical (−6° to −12°), astronomical (−12° to −18°).
items.how_it_works: As the Sun drops, scattered light diminishes; astronomical twilight ends near −18°, after which the sky is darkest under clear, moonless conditions.
items.typical_values_note: Angles in degrees; times depend on latitude/season.
observational_cues: Terminator line on maps; per‑location twilight class shading; photography windows.
items.common_misconceptions: “Astronomical darkness starts at sunset.” Darkness progresses through twilight stages.

items.title: Solar Wind at L1 (Speed, Density, Temperature)
items.summary: Upstream solar-wind conditions measured near L1 determine the near-term energy input to Earth’s magnetosphere.
items.what_it_is: Plasma parameters measured by spacecraft near the Sun–Earth L1 point (~1.5 million km upstream): bulk speed, proton density, temperature, and dynamic pressure.
items.how_it_works: Higher speed/density/pressure increase magnetospheric compression; combined with southward IMF Bz, they drive stronger geomagnetic responses.
items.typical_values_note: Speed ~300–800 km·s⁻¹; density ~1–20 cm⁻³; dynamic pressure typically ~1–5 nPa.
observational_cues: Time series for speed/density/temperature/pressure with threshold shading; nowcast arrows indicating expected magnetospheric response.
items.common_misconceptions: “High speed alone guarantees storms.” Coupling efficiency depends strongly on IMF orientation (Bz).

items.title: Substorms & Auroral Dynamics
items.summary: Short, explosive energy releases in the magnetotail rapidly intensify and reshape aurora.
items.what_it_is: A three‑phase process (growth, expansion, recovery) involving tail reconnection and auroral brightening/poleward expansion.
items.how_it_works: Energy stored in the magnetotail is released, driving particle injections and enhanced ionospheric currents (AE/AL spikes).
items.typical_values_note: Durations tens of minutes to a few hours; AE can exceed 1000 nT during active phases.
observational_cues: Keograms/time‑height summaries; oval expansion; AL/AE indices; westward traveling surges.
items.common_misconceptions: “Substorm equals geomagnetic storm.” Substorms can occur without major global storms.

items.title: Thermosphere Density & Satellite Drag
items.summary: Geomagnetic heating increases thermospheric density and satellite drag, accelerating orbital decay.
items.what_it_is: The upper-atmospheric density (roughly 150–600 km) that sets aerodynamic drag on low‑Earth‑orbit spacecraft.
items.how_it_works: Enhanced EUV and geomagnetic energy input raise exospheric temperature, expanding the thermosphere and increasing density at a given altitude. Drag scales with density and velocity squared.
items.typical_values_note: Density changes can be factors of 2–10 at LEO altitudes during storms; drag acceleration in m·s⁻² depends on spacecraft properties.
observational_cues: Storm-time “drag multiplier” overlays vs quiet baseline; altitude‑dependent density estimates.
items.common_misconceptions: “Only very low satellites are affected.” Even ~400–500 km orbits can experience notable decay during strong storms.

items.title: Tides: Spring/Neap, Perigee Effects & Storm Surge Context
items.summary: Astronomical tides modulate baseline sea level; phase and range can amplify or mitigate weather-driven surge.
items.what_it_is: Semi‑diurnal/diurnal ocean tides forced by lunar/solar gravity; spring tides (new/full) have larger ranges, neap (quarter phases) smaller. Perigee increases tidal range.
items.how_it_works: Constructive/destructive interference of tidal constituents and local resonance shape range; pairing with storm surge determines flood risk.
items.typical_values_note: Tidal ranges vary by basin (cm to meters).
observational_cues: Tide predictions; spring/neap markers; surge model overlays; flood thresholds.
items.common_misconceptions: “Supermoon alone causes flooding.” Surge, waves, and local geometry often dominate impacts.

items.title: Zodiacal Light & Ecliptic Geometry
items.summary: Sunlight scattering off interplanetary dust creates a faint cone along the ecliptic, best seen in dark, clear skies.
items.what_it_is: A diffuse night-sky glow aligned with the ecliptic plane; the gegenschein is an antisolar brightening.
items.how_it_works: Forward scattering by dust grains enhances brightness near the Sun’s direction after dusk/before dawn; geometry with the ecliptic controls visibility by season and latitude.
items.typical_values_note: Surface brightness in mag·arcsec⁻² (faint; easily drowned by light pollution or moonlight).
observational_cues: Ecliptic path overlays; seasonal visibility windows; light‑pollution masks; moon position/phase.
items.common_misconceptions: “Zodiacal light is the Milky Way.” They can be confused by new observers.
